The NDE of sales performance on job satisfaction is calculated as follows:

NDE = P(job satisfaction high | sales performance low, exercise constant) - P(job satisfaction high | sales performance high, exercise constant)

From the given data:

Assuming that exercise is kept constant at low:

NDE = 0.9007 - 0.9359 = -0.0352

Since the NDE is negative, it means that sales performance has a negative direct effect on job satisfaction when the amount of exercise is kept constant. Therefore, if sales performance is changed to be low, job satisfaction would have been less likely to be high.

To determine whether the arrival time would have been more likely to be early if the mediator (public transportation availability) is kept constant when travel time is changed to be long, we need to analyze the natural direct effect (NDE) of travel time on arrival time.

Given the information:

- When travel time is long and traffic congestion is light:
  - Probability of arrival time being early: 0.1020

- When travel time is short and traffic congestion is light:
  - Probability of arrival time being early: 0.4773

- When travel time is long and traffic congestion is heavy:
  - Probability of arrival time being early: 0.0964

- When travel time is short and traffic congestion is heavy:
  - Probability of arrival time being early: 0.4343

- Probability of traffic congestion being light: 0.5488

First, we calculate the probability of arrival time being early when travel time is long:

\[
\text{P(Arrival Early | Travel Time Long)} = \text{P(Arrival Early | Travel Time Long, Traffic Congestion Light)} \times \text{P(Traffic Congestion Light)} + \text{P(Arrival Early | Travel Time Long, Traffic Congestion Heavy)} \times \text{P(Traffic Congestion Heavy)}
\]

\[
= 0.1020 \times 0.5488 + 0.0964 \times (1 - 0.5488)
\]

\[
= 0.1020 \times 0.5488 + 0.0964 \times 0.4512
\]

\[
= 0.0559776 + 0.04354848
\]

\[
= 0.100
\]

Next, we calculate the probability of arrival time being early when travel time is short:

\[
\text{P(Arrival Early | Travel Time Short)} = \text{P(Arrival Early | Travel Time Short, Traffic Congestion Light)} \times \text{P(Traffic Congestion Light)} + \text{P(Arrival Early | Travel Time Short, Traffic Congestion Heavy)} \times \text{P(Traffic Congestion Heavy)}
\]

\[
= 0.4773 \times 0.5488 + 0.4343 \times (1 - 0.5488)
\]

\[
= 0.4773 \times 0.5488 + 0.4343 \times 0.4512
\]

\[
= 0.26195824 + 0.19606296
\]

\[
= 0.4580
\]

Comparing the two probabilities:

\[
\text{P(Arrival Early | Travel Time Long)} = 0.100
\]
\[
\text{P(Arrival Early | Travel Time Short)} = 0.4580
\]

Since 0.100 < 0.4580, the arrival time would have been more likely to be early if travel time is kept constant at short.
